A particle continuously moves in a circular path at constant speed in a counterclockwise direction. Consider a time interval during which the particle moves along this circular path from point P to point Q. Point Q is exactly half-way around the circle from Point P.<image 1>What is the direction of the average velocity during this time interval?

A. rightward
B. leftward
C. upward
D. The average velocity is zero.

To determine the direction of the average velocity during the time interval from point P to point Q, we need to consider the direction of the particle's motion and the direction of the average velocity.

The particle moves in a counterclockwise direction along a circular path. The average velocity is the displacement per unit time, which is the change in position divided by the change in time.

During the time interval from point P to point Q, the particle moves from point P to point Q. Since the particle moves counterclockwise, the displacement from P to Q is in the direction of the positive x-axis (assuming the circular path is in the first quadrant).

The average velocity is the change in position divided by the change in time. Since the particle moves from P to Q, the change in position is from P to Q, and the change in time is the time interval during which the particle moves from P to Q.

The change in position is from P to Q, which is a straight line from P to Q. The change in time is the time interval during which the particle moves from P to Q, which is the distance from P to Q divided by the speed of the particle.

The speed of the particle is constant and positive, as the particle moves in a counterclockwise direction. Therefore, the average velocity is also positive.

Therefore, the direction of the average velocity during this time interval is rightward.

The correct answer is A.
